context_of_use: The IFA configures the platform infrastructure to integrate existing systems, support multiple languages, and maintain required reliability for concurrent users.
stakeholders_and_interests: IFA: Wants to avoid redundant data storage by integrating existing systems into a unified platform.
IFA: Wants to support multiple languages within the system to service leagues in different countries.
IFA: Wants the system to reliably support at least 50,000 concurrent users to ensure a satisfactory user experience.
Users of existing systems: Want their existing data to be accessible without duplication after integration.
Leagues in different countries: Want league data and tools accessible in appropriate languages.
All end users of the platform: Want stable and responsive system behavior during peak concurrent usage.
description: This use case describes how the IFA configures the system infrastructure to integrate existing systems for unified data access, enable multiple language support, and ensure that the platform maintains reliability for at least 50,000 concurrent users.
triggering_event: The IFA decides to configure or update the system infrastructure to integrate existing systems, enable language support, and meet the targeted concurrent user reliability.
preconditions: The IFA Integrated League Management System is deployed and accessible to the IFA.
The IFA has administrative authority to configure system infrastructure settings.
Existing systems to be integrated are operational and accessible through defined interfaces or connectivity.
Target languages to be supported are identified by the IFA.
The required concurrent user capacity target of at least 50,000 users is defined by the IFA as an infrastructure goal.
postconditions: Existing systems selected by the IFA are integrated so that relevant data is accessible without redundant storage in the platform.
Multiple language options configured by the IFA are available within the system for supported user interfaces and data labels.
System infrastructure configuration is set to maintain reliability for at least 50,000 concurrent users according to the IFA-defined reliability criteria.
The configured integration, language settings, and reliability parameters are stored and will be applied to subsequent system operations.
assumptions: It is assumed that all existing systems to be integrated expose interfaces or data access mechanisms that can be connected to the IFA Integrated League Management System without requiring new functional capabilities beyond integration configuration.

It is assumed that the IFA defines what constitutes acceptable reliability at 50,000 concurrent users in terms of performance and availability, and that this definition is already available to the system as configuration criteria.
It is assumed that supported languages are predefined within the system or available through configuration files, and that the IFA only selects and configures from this predefined set.
It is assumed that the IFA has the necessary technical information about existing systems, such as connection endpoints and data mapping rules, before starting the configuration.

It is assumed that infrastructure capacity such as servers, network, and storage is provisioned outside this use case and can be configured within defined limits, without requiring the system to automatically procure additional hardware or cloud resources.
It is assumed that the IFA performs configuration activities via a secured administrative interface of the IFA Integrated League Management System.

It is assumed that monitoring and diagnostic information required to assess concurrent user reliability is already available to the system and can be interpreted according to existing system capabilities.
requirements_met: The system shall allow the IFA to configure integration of different existing systems so that redundant data storage is minimized.
The system shall allow the IFA to define or select which existing systems are to be integrated into the platform.
The system shall, after integration configuration, access data from integrated existing systems instead of requiring redundant data to be re-entered or stored separately.
The system shall allow the IFA to configure support for multiple languages within the system user interface.
The system shall allow the IFA to select which languages are active for use by leagues in different countries.
The system shall present system content in the languages configured as active by the IFA, in accordance with existing localization capabilities.
The system shall be configurable by the IFA to maintain system reliability for at least 50,000 concurrent users based on pre-established reliability criteria.

The system shall provide the IFA with relevant configuration parameters that influence system reliability for concurrent users, such as concurrency thresholds and resource usage limits, within the system’s existing capability set.
The system shall store and apply the IFA’s infrastructure configuration related to system integration, language support, and reliability settings.
The system shall provide feedback to the IFA indicating whether the configured integration, language settings, and reliability parameters have been successfully applied.
outstanding_issues: The specific technical interfaces and protocols required to integrate each existing system have not been defined and may affect feasibility and configuration complexity.
The detailed quantitative definition of "maintain system reliability" at 50,000 concurrent users, including acceptable response times and uptime levels, has not been fully specified.
The full list of languages to be supported and the extent of localization coverage (for example, data labels only or full content translation) have not been finalized.
The method by which the IFA validates that configured reliability settings are sufficient for 50,000 concurrent users has not been specified.
Security and access control policies governing which IFA roles may perform infrastructure configuration have not been explicitly defined.
main_flow: 1. IFA initiates infrastructure configuration through the administrative interface → System displays available infrastructure configuration sections, including system integration, language support, and reliability settings.
2. IFA selects the system integration configuration section → System displays a list of configurable existing systems and integration options.

3. IFA selects which existing systems to integrate and specifies required connection and data mapping parameters → System validates the provided integration parameters against existing connectivity and data format rules and shows the configured integration set.
4. IFA confirms the integration configuration for the selected existing systems → System applies the integration configuration and stores integration settings for subsequent data access.
5. IFA selects the language support configuration section → System displays the list of languages that can be enabled within the system.
6. IFA selects one or more languages to be supported and, if applicable, sets a default system language → System validates the language selections and updates the language configuration preview.
7. IFA confirms the language support configuration → System applies the language configuration, stores it, and prepares user-facing components to use the configured language options.

8. IFA selects the reliability configuration section related to concurrent user capacity → System displays configuration parameters relevant to supporting at least 50,000 concurrent users, according to existing capabilities.

9. IFA adjusts reliability-related configuration parameters as needed to meet the 50,000 concurrent user target based on defined criteria → System validates the parameters against allowed ranges and displays the resulting reliability configuration summary.

10. IFA confirms and saves the overall infrastructure configuration, including integration, language, and reliability settings → System persists all configuration changes and confirms successful application of the new infrastructure configuration, indicating that integration, language support, and reliability settings are now active.
alternative_flows: AF-1 (from Step 3): IFA configures only a subset of available existing systems for integration. Condition: The IFA decides not to integrate all listed existing systems. The IFA selects only certain existing systems and provides connection and data mapping parameters for this subset. The system validates only the selected integrations, shows the configured subset, and the flow continues with Step 4.

AF-2 (from Step 6): IFA enables only a single language for the system. Condition: The IFA chooses to operate the system in one language at this time. The IFA selects a single language and designates it as the default. The system validates the configuration, updates the language configuration preview accordingly, and the flow continues with Step 7.

AF-3 (from Step 9): IFA accepts recommended default reliability configuration. Condition: The system presents a default configuration that the IFA deems sufficient for supporting at least 50,000 concurrent users. The IFA reviews but does not change the recommended reliability parameters. The system confirms that the default parameters meet the predefined target and the flow continues with Step 10.
exception_flows: EF-1 (from Step 3): Integration parameter validation fails. Condition: One or more connection or data mapping parameters specified for an existing system are invalid according to system rules. The system rejects the invalid entries, displays error messages indicating which parameters are incorrect, and requests corrected values. The use case continues when the IFA provides valid parameters and the system successfully validates them, after which the flow proceeds with Step 4. If the IFA chooses to cancel the configuration, the system discards unsaved integration changes and the use case ends without applying new integration settings.

EF-2 (from Step 6): Selected language is not supported by the system. Condition: The IFA attempts to select a language that is not in the list of supported languages. The system rejects the unsupported language selection, informs the IFA that the language cannot be enabled, and prompts the IFA to select from supported languages. The use case continues when the IFA selects only supported languages and the system validates the configuration, after which the flow proceeds with Step 7.

EF-3 (from Step 9): Reliability configuration parameters exceed allowed limits. Condition: The IFA specifies reliability-related parameters that are outside the permitted range or conflict with existing capacity constraints. The system rejects the excessive or inconsistent settings, displays explanatory messages, and requests that the IFA adjust the parameters to within allowable bounds. The use case continues when the IFA provides acceptable parameters and the system validates them, after which the flow proceeds with Step 10.

EF-4 (from Step 10): Failure to persist configuration changes. Condition: A system or storage error occurs while saving the new infrastructure configuration. The system notifies the IFA that configuration changes could not be saved, logs the failure according to existing logging mechanisms, and retains the previous configuration as active. The use case ends with no new configuration applied.
information_for_steps: 1. Administrative session identifier, IFA credentials, configuration section identifiers.
2. List of available existing systems, integration option identifiers, selection status.
3. Selected system identifiers, connection endpoints, authentication parameters, data mapping definitions, validation results.
4. Confirmed integration configuration set, stored integration profiles, integration status indicators.
5. Language configuration section metadata, list of supported language codes and names.
6. Selected language codes, designated default language, validation results for language configuration.
7. Persisted language configuration settings, active language set, default language flag.
8. Reliability configuration section metadata, current concurrency capacity parameters, recommended defaults.
9. Updated reliability-related parameters, such as concurrency thresholds and resource allocation settings within existing capability limits, validation results, reliability configuration summary.
10. Aggregated configuration payload including integration, language, and reliability settings, persistence status, confirmation message content.
